E.	Five Year Accident History (Update)
- No RMP reportable accidents have been recorded or have occurred at the ECGS in the last five (5) years.

F.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
- The procedures and equipment that are described in this RMP for detecting unplanned releases of anhydrous ammonia and for responding in the event of such a release are currently being implemented at the ECGS and have been applied since the initial installation of the ammonia system (1992).

A.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Policies in Place at Facility
- ECGS will comply with the CalARP and the RMP Programs.
- A copy of the Contingency Plan and Emergency Response Procedures for El Centro Steam Plant prepared for the IID is located at the facility as part of the CalARP Program documentation.
 
B.	Description of Regulated Processes and Regulated Substances Handled
- The primary activity of the ECGS is generation of electric power.
- The only regulated substance used in an amount triggering the CalARP/RMP program is anhydrous ammonia, which will be used as the reagent for the SCR emission control technology installed on the power generating units.
- The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia to be stored on-site will be approximately 12,000 gallons or 60,000 pounds.  

C.	Worst-Case Ammonia Release Scenario and Alternative Release Scenario for Anhydrous Ammonia
- The worst-case release scenario information is located in the 2022 Hazard Assessment report completed by Risk Management Professionals.

D.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program

- Other important safety features are discussed throughout this RMP.

     - All ammonia piping and equipment has been constructed in a manner to minimize the necessary amount of piping used in the system.

Transport of Anhydrous ammonia to ECGS is accomplished by using tanker trucks, with individual deliveries of about 5,000 to 7,000 gallons per delivery. When the units are operating, a delivery is scheduled every three (3) to five (5) weeks.

The 12,000-gallon horizontal storage tank has an outside diameter of 9-feet with a length of 23-feet and 5-inches.  The Ammonia Storage Tank is located inside an enclosure that is adjacent to the unloading area.  The floor beneath the storage tank is slightly sloped towards a sump (with drain) in the north western corner of the enclosure.  This area is sloped to contain and drain accidental spills.  In addition, the ammonia-handling facility is equipped with extensive ammonia detection and alarm systems to protect workers and equipment in the event of a malfunction anywhere within the system.

The use of equipment for the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia in support of the SCR project will require compliance with several environmental and safety regulatory requirements, including preparation of this RMP pursuant to the CalARP Program.  The quantity of ammonia on-site also triggers the federal RMP program pursuant to Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act.  An RMP is required under the CalARP program and at the discretion of the local administering agency (AA).  In Imperial County, the AA is the Department of Toxic Substance Control (DTSC), which also is the local Unified Program Agency (UPA).  The DTSC has informed the ECGS that an RMP will be required in connection with the anhydrous ammonia system in operation at their facilities. 

This document is the RMP prepared for submittal to DTSC to address the facility for the unloading, storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia at the ECGS.  The organization of the RMP closely follows that recommended in the CalARP Program Gu

El Centro Generating Station (ECGS), located at 485 East Villa Road, El Centro, California operates four (4) power generation units along with Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) technology to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx) for three combustion turbines.   SCR is a post-combustion flue gas NOX emission control technology that speeds up reaction process for removal of NOX from the flue gas downstream from the combustion process.  A reducing agent is used to reduce NOX emissions, primarily nitric oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), by oxidation-reduction reactions in the presence of a catalyst.  The most common reducing agent (reagent) used with SCR is ammonia.  Injection of the correct ammonia/air mixture into the combustion exhaust stream before the catalyst, initiates the reactions and achieves the desired removal of NOx emissions upstream from the stack.  The ECGS uses anhydrous ammonia (60,000 pounds) as the reagent for the SCR reactions. For this purpose, ECGS stores 60,000 pounds or 12,000 gallons in a single ammonia storage tank.

Due to the hazardous nature of anhydrous ammonia, ECGS is required to develop and implement specific regulatory requirements, enforced by both local and federal government agencies, including Federal Risk Management Plan (RMP), Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), Process Safety Management (PSM), and a Seismic Analysis (SA) of the facilities, operations, and equipment.    All regulatory requirements for the use and storage of anhydrous ammonia at the ECGS are found within:
- Title 40 Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations;
- Title 20 Section 1910.119 of the Code of Federal Regulations; and
- Sections 25531 - 25543.3 of the California Health and Safety Code.
